body: I think we should get this in, but I'd like to try to do it when we move from com.netflix packages to org.apache. That is going to touch every file as well, so we may as well do it at the same time.
Is there any way we could build this more incrementally? 10,000 lines is a lot of code to review.
@YuvalItzchakov are you still working on this? If not then I can take this up.

Sorry, but I'm still not getting why this is necessary.

For example #1, why wouldn't you just add a "source" column to the data? That way you could do something like `DELETE FROM table WHERE source = "bad_source_id"`

For example 2, why is a secondary identity required? Can the external system not identify files by path? What would happen to this metadata when data files are merged? I'm reluctant to add a user metadata field that prevents maintenance because we don't know how to fill it in.
@mccheah, thanks for working on this! It's about ready to go, but we need to change back to using String instead of URI. There's also an unnecessary rename that we should remove.
What's the timeline for that? Should we start doing both sets of changes now?
I'm happy to help review this. Can you provide a basic usage example?
@vinooganesh @yifeih @rdblue

I think this API should pass in the partition tuple. Now that I think about it, the metadata location is determined by the `TableOperations` implementation, not by `FileIO`. I think it would make sense to keep those in the same place. So `TableOperations` would be responsible for determining where to place both metadata and data files, while `FileIO` would just handle low-level file tasks.
Thanks for opening this. I agree, we need to switch over to org.apache package names before the first Apache release.
I don't have a timeline yet, but I'd like to get it done in the next few weeks. I've added blocking issues to the 0.1.0 release milestone.
Spec changes are here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Q-zL5lSCle6NEEdyfiYsXYzX_Q8Qf0ctMyGBKslOswA/edit#heading=h.llpzlfgcw6g2

@mccheah It may be difficult to break up because there is a lot of interdependency.  I'll see what I can do to break apart some of the packages.

@xhochy The actual core part of the library is still incomplete, the best place to start looking is in the iceberg.api package.  You can see examples of usage in the tests/api folder.  Let me know if you have any questions and I'm happy to answer, I appreciate you taking a look.

@xhochy, great to see you in the Iceberg community!

I think we could use some help making sure the API looks pythonic. @TGooch44 has done a great job porting the Java library over to Python, including tests for the components so we are fairly confident that what it is doing matches the behavior of Java and is correct. But there are some cases where the code is probably quite odd to pythonistas, like the translation of Java interfaces that throw a RuntimeError instead of allowing dynamic typing to throw NoSuchMethodError. Your opinion on those areas would be appreciated!

@aokolnychyi, this PR avoids using Spark's WriteSupport for Parquet. It would be interesting to see which option performs better. My initial testing shows this new write path takes about 48 seconds for 500,000 random records where the Spark WriteSupport takes about 52.
@rdblue I'll give it a try in a few days

We can have small files committed as part of ETL/Streaming operations. An obvious next step is to create a job which can over-write files to create more compacted files. Spark module currently only supports "Append" while creating a writer. For over-writing files, there is a need to extend the writer to support other modes as well.  We already have [overWrite](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/api/src/main/java/com/netflix/iceberg/OverwriteFiles.java) and [rewriteFile](https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/core/src/main/java/com/netflix/iceberg/ReplaceFiles.java) APIs. Can they be used to implement the new functionality? 

cc @rdblue @prakharjain09

@prakharjain09, Spark is removing SaveMode because it has unreliable behavior. Instead, Spark is introducing overwrite APIs that match some of the APIs that Iceberg supports. See `SupportsDynamicOverwrite` and `SupportsOverwrite` in the latest [Spark DSv2 design doc](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1vI26UEuDpVuOjWw4WPoH2T6y8WAekwtI7qoowhOFnI4/edit#).

When Spark supports those, Iceberg will be able to support overwrite.
Thank you for looking at this @xhochy! I think your suggestions sound reasonable.

@xhochy I really appreciate all the review, I'll go through these and review, but as Ryan mentioned it all sounds reasonable, so unless I have any questions I'll start implementing everything  you've suggested.
Looks like Travis timed out for some reason.  Can someone with access to it restart the run for this PR?
@jghoman, CI builds are currently broken and we're waiting on a fix PR from a contributor that found the problem. I'll restart this after it is merged. Thanks for submitting a fix!
Thanks for fixing this, @aokolnychyi!

@mccheah, I think this is just about ready to merge, but it doesn't need most of the calls to strip slashes. Once those are fixed, I'll merge it. No rush since you're probably just back from the holidays.
Almost there, addressed the comments, fixed the merge conflicts.
Ok I'll start taking a look at this now!

Remark: The paths module has to be a separate entity because once again, we will be instantiating it once on the driver and serializing the instance for executors. I think we can move the metadata file lookup to this module as well.
Merged. Thanks @mccheah!
@rdblue Please review
@mccheah, in that case is this something that we should add to the `FileIO` interface? It wouldn't be that much of a stretch to do path selection as well. What do you think?
Yup I don't have a strong opinion here, so let's bundle it with the FileIO interface. I'll propose a diff but I anticipate wanting to fine tune the exact method signatures as part of the PR review.
@aokolnychyi, this is a fix for the issue you pointed out. Could you please review? Thank you!

I have a local benchmark that compares writing 5000000 records in Parquet format using gzip compression via Iceberg and via Spark native file source.

Here are the results with this PR:
```
Benchmark                                           Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SparkParquetFlatDataWriteBenchmark.writeFileSource    ss    5  4.587 ± 0.226   s/op
SparkParquetFlatDataWriteBenchmark.writeIceberg       ss    5  4.537 ± 0.090   s/op
```

```
Benchmark                                             Mode  Cnt  Score   Error  Units
SparkParquetNestedDataWriteBenchmark.writeFileSource    ss    5  8.798 ± 0.342   s/op
SparkParquetNestedDataWriteBenchmark.writeIceberg       ss    5  8.457 ± 0.282   s/op
```

This PR is also critical as Iceberg will collect proper metadata per file (e.g., min/max values). As for now, we only keep track of the number of rows during writes via Iceberg Spark data source.
For apache projects, artifacts should be published to the apache maven repository (they will be automatically available on the central repository as well).
Thanks @aokolnychyi! Looks like it isn't faster, but at least it isn't slower.
@aokolnychyi, @mccheah, can you review this PR?
Thanks for fixing this, @jghoman!

I will share the benchmarking code later and we can discuss if the test is valid or not. Overall, I saw that the performance on flat data is very close but Iceberg is a bit faster on nested data.

I have more benchmarks for the read path. There are also interesting moments.

Hey @rdblue  I just pushed a PR for this issue
https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/75

Thanks for working on this @renato2099!

Like the version by @Liorba, this can't be committed until the transforms support inclusive projections of the `startsWith` predicate. Otherwise, the inclusive projection will be null and the predicate will be converted to `alwaysTrue` to match partition values resulting in much larger than necessary table scans.

For background, a projection is the predicate converted to work on partition values. The *inclusive* projection is one that must match any partition that contains a matching value, even if those partitions contain values that don't match. (The *strict* projection is one that matches a partition if all values in the partition must match the original predicate.)

For example, if a table is partitioned by `part0=truncate(str, 4)` then partitions are created by taking the first 4 characters of column `str`. The inclusive projection of `startsWith(str, "aa")` is `startWith(part0, "aa")` because all values that match the predicate must be in partitions that start with "aa". Similarly, the inclusive projection of `startsWith(str, "aaaaa")` is `startsWith(part0, "aaaa")` or `equal(part0, "aaaa")` because all values that match must be in partition "aaaa". Note that the partition "aaaa" also includes the value "aaaab" that doesn't match the original data predicate, which is why we call it the "inclusive" projection.
This was fixed by #52.

After talking with @vinooganesh, @yifeih, and @mccheah, we decided that the use case was to be able to hook into the logic that creates file paths. The partition information stored for each DataFile is the "logical" path for a file so the need is just to set the physical path. This generalizes the object storage vs folder storage feature, so it makes sense to allow `TableOperations` or `FileIO` to control data file paths.

Superseded by #55.

Thanks for the feedback @rdblue! 
I see what you mean, I wasn't aware of this. I have a few questions about it though:
- So regarding the transform for `startsWith` should it go in its own class com.netflix.iceberg.transforms.StartsWith? or should it just go into com.netflix.iceberg.transforms.Transforms? I know it will go for sure into com.netflix.iceberg.expressions.Projections as well
- When using this `startsWith(part0, 'aaaa')`, does it also mean adding a PartitionSpec method?
- I guess that when using `startsWith(part0, 'aaaa')`, we would only have at most two partitions, where is this taken into account? I guess this is used on the read and write path, could you point me to that part of the code?
- A clarification question. What do you mean by: " a projection is the predicate converted to work on partition values."? 
Thanks in advanced!
This LGTM. Thanks!
Thanks for reviewing @aokolnychyi and @Parth-Brahmbhatt!

Also worth highlighting is that the last commit is a conflict resolution where I also moved the metadata location configuration into `HadoopFileIO` but it's not clear if I did that correctly, though tests pass.

We can follow up with a PR to get rid of script runner if that works. For now, let's get this fix committed. Thanks @aokolnychyi!
I'll give it a try and let you know

@mccheah, thanks for working on this. It's looking close, but I have doubts about adding `TableOperations#io(TableMetadata)`. I'd rather add `FileIO#updateMetadata(TableMetadata)` if you think it is necessary to have the behavior that requires `io(TableMetadata)`.

Otherwise, I think this is about ready to get in.

Ok now this represents the current state of the proposal document in its entirety.
Let's prepare to do this after https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/pull/69

Thanks for catching this, @xabriel. Looks like a reasonable set of changes to me.

The only problem I have is that this should be configurable for systems that are case sensitive. If Iceberg should not impose case sensitivity on processing engines then it shouldn't impose case insensitivity either.

I think this needs that configuration before the binder behavior change can be committed. The binder should probably accept a case sensitivity boolean argument, and that should be passed through to make this work in Spark.

If you want, we could separate this into the changes here other than updating the behavior of Binder, then add the rest in a follow-up. Up to you how you want to move forward.
I should also note that we could also update Spark to pass the correct case back to v2 sources. That's probably a good idea either way.

After trying to build on top of this work to do the actual encryption/decryption in the Spark data source, I realized that some parts of the API led to potential inconsistencies. Instead of trying to highlight them here though, I'll post the prototype that does the actual encryption so that we can more concretely explain why certain changes had to be made.

Notice that `EncryptionKeyMetadata` is now holding the `cipherAlgorithm` and `keyAlgorithm` explicitly, as well as the removal of the intermediate layer of `FileEncryptionMetadata`.

Thanks for the feedback, @rdblue.

> If Iceberg should not impose case sensitivity on processing engines then it shouldn't impose case insensitivity either.

Agreed.

I'll go ahead and update the PR to:
1) Update `Binder#bind` to accept a `caseSensitive` parameter. Update tests accordingly.
2) Not change default behavior.

As suggested, I'll submit a follow up PR for using the new functionality.
Mentioned this above, but see https://github.com/mccheah/incubator-iceberg/pull/1 for a target follow-up commit that would use these APIs in Spark.

Actually, we need to revert this change. I was too quick with my analysis.

I missed the point that the config passed to `ObjectStore$setConf` is actually persisted for future use. `MetastoreConf$newMetastoreConf` is the ONLY one that is printed but it is used as a basis to create an instance of `PersistenceManagerFactory`. It has no real effect.

So, `SCHEMA_VERIFICATION` and `AUTO_CREATE_ALL` seem to be redundant as we have `ScriptRunner`. I also double-checked that not all tables are created, as @Parth-Brahmbhatt said.

Out of curiosity, why none of the test failed after we removed the configs? Aren't the removed configs related to Hive ACID tables? Does Iceberg rely on those configs?
Looks good to me. Thanks for catching this error, @jzhuge!
Conflicts in a lot of places. Think it would be great to take a look at this soon - would like this to unblock code linting work for 1.x too.

Yeah, I haven't looked at this much because I think we will want to plan when we switch over. It will break other pull requests. It's also a fairly simple change in an IDE, so I wouldn't worry about the conflicts. We can just refactor when the time comes.

Thanks for the update, @xabriel!

Adding a `caseSensitive` flag requires quite a few updates elsewhere, and method calls are less readable because of the boolean argument (we'll forget what `true` signals). What do you think about adding versions of these methods that don't have the flag and default to case sensitive?

The drawback is that it will be easy to not pay attention later and use case sensitive matching when it shouldn't be. But I think that would be okay. At least for tests, a package-private version that defaults to case sensitive would cut down on a lot of code changes.

What do you think?

> What do you think about adding versions of these methods that don't have the flag and default to case sensitive?

I do think that that users of `Binder#bind` should be forced to make a choice, otherwise iceberg will evolve, get new committers, and some future PR will use default behavior from `Binder#bind(StructType struct, Expression expr)`, thus inadvertently not honoring the new configuration flag that would come in a follow up PR to this one.

> At least for tests, a package-private version that defaults to case sensitive would cut down on a lot of code changes.

A package-private version its ok with me if you think it will make this PR easier to follow. No problem.


So to summarize:
1) We will have `Binder#bind(StructType struct, Expression expr)` as package-private, thus existing tests will change minimally.
2) `Binder#bind(StructType struct, Expression expr, boolean caseSensitive)` to be used by all non-test callers.

Agreed?
@xabriel, sounds good to me. Thanks!

We still need follow up PRs to:

2) Also need to address a comment from @rdblue on #82:
>  I think some of these Evaluators will also need case sensitivity options. It doesn't do much good to support it in expression binding if it isn't also exposed when working with expressions in other ways. Can you also open a follow-up issue?
Merged. Thank you for contributing this, @xabriel!
Integrated into Spark from https://github.com/mccheah/incubator-iceberg/pull/2.
Ok I adjusted this such that `TableOperations` only has the single `io()` method. We now offer a metadata-aware IO method in `BaseMetastoreTableOperations` though, to maintain existing behavior.
To override FileIO generation for subclasses of `BaseMetastoreTableOperations` though, devs should override `BaseMetastoreTableOperations#metadataAwareFileIO`.
Good idea. Any suggestion for the default open cost?
It seems it is better to overestimate a bit. By default, Spark sets it to 4MB. I think we can try some numbers below and above and see what performs better.
Okay, let's start with 4 MB. We can update it when we have better data.
@mccheah, here are the LocationProvider changes. Can you take a look? I didn't port your tests over.
@Parth-Brahmbhatt, FYI. This adds an interface that provides data file locations so the table implementation can control them. Eventually, it would be good if Presto supported that pattern.
I don't know why tests are still passing, but I'm reluctant to change anything back unless it is a problem.

It seems the config params that were moved to `metastore-site.xml` are needed only for Hive ACID tables. If that's the case, we can simply remove `metastore-site.xml` in a follow-up PR as Iceberg does not need those configs.

Hey @rdblue I did a pass on this, but I am not sure this was the intended way. I understand the high level idea but as I am not very familiar with the code I just gave it a shot by following other transformation implementations. Happy to update as neeed 👍

This uses the configuration for table commit retries, which isn't appropriate for this situation. Here, the operation is adding metadata for manifest files that were written without metadata. It is very unlikely that the operation needs a retry for S3 because the files are not new.

I think this retry should actually be removed. It was originally intended to catch the case that is now handled in HadoopOutputFile#toInputFile.
@rdblue do you want me to close this PR and create a new one removing the retry or repurpose this PR instead and drop the retry altogether?
You can go ahead and do it here.
@renato2099, can you rebase on master? Picking the commits into this branch makes them show up as your changes and it is hard to see what you're proposing.

@renato2099, looking just at the last commit, I don't think that's the right approach. What you built was a transform, but you're trying to implement a predicate. You need to update the project methods in existing transforms to support projecting your new startsWith predicate.

Afaik `Object.finalize()` isn't the best option out there for resource reclaiming, unless it's the only option, is it in this particular case?
I'm thinking if it would work if we were to be looking into more naive alternatives such as having `HadoopSeekableInputStream` and `HadoopPositionOutputStream` both implement (which they already do) `java.lang.AutoCloseable` and just rely on always using `try-with-resources` when working with `com.netflix.iceberg.io.SeekableInputStream` instances from `com.netflix.iceberg.hadoop.HadoopStreams#wrap(org.apache.hadoop.fs.FSDataInputStream)`?

I'm calling object finalization not the best option because of the usual reasons: it's basically nondeterministic since it depends on GC firing (that's basically a bunch of heuristics, might as well roll a dice), no guarantees to be called before program exits, no guarantees on the ordering in which JVM will invoke the objects' finalizer methods, all finalizers are treated "fairly" so objects holding on to considerable resources are queued up waiting for objects whose finalizers are slowly progressing, etc.  of and also seeing as `Object.finalize()` has become deprecated with [Java 9](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/9/docs/api/java/lang/Object.html#finalize--) (most probably not going to go away any time soon though)

@fbocse, this is not the intended way to clean up resources. This is a way to handle leaks so that you get nice warning messages instead of failing applications when a resource pool runs out.

Iceberg already uses try-with-resources and is careful about cleaning up open files internally, but it also returns open streams to callers as `CloseableIterable` instances. If callers leave those open, a finalizer is better than doing nothing.
